Arithmeticall meane between the two extreames: contrary to w[hat]
happens in the colours made by the refraction of a Prism, wh[en?]
the Red is most contracted, the violet most expanded, and [in]
the midst of them is the confine of Green & Blew.
Obs: 15. These Rings were not of various colours like those 
in the open air, but appeared all ouer of that Prismatique colour only 
with wch they were illuminated. And by projecting the Prismatique 
colours imediatly upon the glasses, I found, that the light wch fell on 
the dark spaces, wch were between the coloured Rings, was transmitted 
through the Glasses without any variac[i]on of colour. For on a white 
paper placed behind, it would paint Rings of the same colour with 
those wch were reflected, & of the bignes of their intermediate  spaces.
And from hence the Origine of these Rings is manifest, namely 
that the Aereall Intervall of the Glasses, according to its various 
thicknes, is disposed in some places to reflect and in others to trans[mit]
the light of any colour, & in the same place to reflect one colour 
where it transmitts another.
Obs: 16. The squares of the Diameters of these Rings made 
by any Prismatique color were in Arithmeticall progression as in the [5th?]
Observac[i]on. and the diameter of the 6th circle when made by 
the yellow & viewed almost p[er]pendicularly, was about 58/100 parts
of an inch, agreeable to the 6th Observac[i]on.
The precedent Observac[i]ons were made with a rarer thin Medium 
terminated by a Denser, such as was air or water compressed betwixt 
two Glasses. In those that follow, are sett downe the appearances 
of a Denser Medium  thin’d within a rarer, such as are plates of 
Moscovy Glasse, Bubbles of water, and some others thin substance 
terminated on all sides with air.
Obs: 17. If a Bubble be blowne wth water, first made tenac[ious?]
by dissoluing a little soap in it, ‘tis a comon Observac[i]on that after 
a while it will appeare tinged with a great variety of colours.
To defend these Bubbles from being agitated by the externall air
(whereby their colours are irregularly moved one among another,
so that no accurate Observac[i]on can be made of them) assoon as 
I had blowne any of them, I covered it with a cleer glasse & by this 
means its colours emerged in a very regular Order like so many 
concentrick Rings incompassing the top of the Bubble. And 
as the Bubble grew thinner by the continuall subsiding 
of the water, these Rings dilated slowly & overspread 
the whole Bubble descending in Order to the bottom of it 
where they vanished successively. In the mean while after 
all the colours were Emerged at the top, there grew in the 
Center of the Rings a small Round black Spott, like that 
in the first Observac[i]on, wch continually dilated it selfe till it 
became somtimes more than 1/2 or 3/4 of an inch in breadth
